discounts: 15% off before 14 Aug 2023, 10% off before 21 Aug 2023
SPML.title: Statistics and Programming
updateFrequency: New content is added to this course daily
SPML.summary:
This beginner-friendly course teaches the core theoretical and practical concepts in statistical inference and, by extension, machine learning. Statistics and ML have broad applications in the real world but many struggle to learn statistics and ML because they don't have a strong foundation in mathematics and programming. 

This course teaches the foundations of mathematics and programming, and enable you to actually understand statistics and machine learning.
SPML.description: Learn the mathematics of data science and statistics.  Includes examples in machine learning and applications from healthcare to finance to engineering. Perform statistical analysis with Python and understand the foundations of bayesian statistical learning.
SPML.descriptionLong:
This courses teaches Statistics and Probability Theory with emphasis on learning from first principles. To learn advanced Statistics and, in particular, Probability Theory, it is necessary to be familiar with other mathematical topics including Integration, Sequences, Series, Sets, and Combinatrics. Although this course has Statistics and Probability Theory in the title, it contains sufficient supplementary material about other mathematical subjects that is necessary for mastery in Statistics and Probability Theory.

This course also teaches R, the programming language for statistical analysis. You will learn the required programming constructs to perform analysis in this specialized programming language. You will learn to apply the appropriate functions and methods, import and process data, produce meaningful visualizations, and interpret the results of analysis (e.g, Correlation, ANOVA, etc.)

rootDocs.title: Google Meet for Live Office Hours

weeks.weekTitle: Module 1 - Overview of Statistics and Machine Learning
weeks.description: n module 1, we will look at how statistical and probabilistic techniques are used in different domains – from healthcare to finance to engineering and other disciplines. We will also look at how machine learning evolved from the science and mathematics of statistics.

weeks.weekTitle: Module 2 - Programming and Scripting: Python and BASH
weeks.description: The true power of statisitcs is realized when we implement descriptive and inferential techniques using computation. In this module, we will learn the programming language, Python, and the scripting languge, BASH. Python is the programming language in machine learning and also widely used in statistics. BASH will be used to manage files and install libraries for our work.

In this module we will introduce two important inferential techniques in classical (or frequentist) statistics: regression analysis and hypothesis testing. We will also look at the concept of likelihood, and, from there, build upon our understanding and work towards the alternative inferential methods of bayesian statistics.

The most central branch of mathematics in statisitcs is probability theory. There are two interpretations of probability theory: frequentist and bayesian. As a result of these different ways of understanding probability, the science of statistics has diverged into two different ways of infering from data. We will see these two interpretations differ and when they are relevant.

Machine Learning has evolved from statistical modeling and algorithmic modeling of computer science. More important, machine learning made it possible to perform statistical and probabilistic inferential techniques on large volumes of data. In this module, we will learn further develop our programming skills by applying them to applications in machine learning.

The Bayesian Theorem (and the algebraic adaptations of it) are at the center of the most powerful machine learning and deep learning models. In this module, we will delve deeper into bayesian methods, discuss the importance of prior and posterior distributions, and understand why bayesian inference is so important in machine learning.

weeks.weekTitle: Module 7 – Calculus and Algebra for Statistics
weeks.description: Statistics is a mathematical science with probability theory at its core. However, probability theory can be properly studies if the mathematical prerequisites are learnt. The prerequisites for probability theory include, among other branches of mathematics, calculus, combinatorics, classical algebra, and basic abstract algebra. We will cover these prerequisites both in live lectures and supplementary learning material.

weeks.weekTitle: Module 8 – Probability Distributions and Machine Learning
weeks.description: In this final learning module, we will study the probability distributions, their applications, and their derivations. It is very important for any statistician, data scientist, or anyone who professionally uses statistics to understand how and why probability functions are expressed the way they are. This module will cover important probability distributions such as binomial distribution, Poission distribution, and the normal distribution.

This module is dedicated to your capstone project, the completion of which is required to earn the certificate for 'Professional Certificate in Statistics and Programing'. Completing this project will involve modeling data, data transformations with Python, visualization, inference and error measurements.

highlights: Beginner-friendly course. Includes advanced content for intermediate learners.
Covers the mathematics and statistics of machine learning.
Intuitive explanations of mathematical and statistical theory
Step-by-step breakdown of complex technical concepts.
Learn through programming, exercises, and practical real-world applications.
First-principles teaching style. Learn from elementary to advanced concepts.
SPML.event: Attend the Course Q&A on TBD to learn more about this program.

discounts: 15% off before 14 Aug 2023, 10% off before 21 Aug 2023

children.title: Derivation of Bayes Theorem X
children.description: In this video, we'll look at the alebraic variations of the Bayes theorem and explain the terms that go into the formulae of the Bayes Theorem.

SPR_.title: Statistics and Programming (Data Science)
updateFrequency: New content is added to this course daily
SPR_.description: Learn the mathematical science behind artificial intelligence, econometrics, risk engineering, and epidemiology. Learn to perform statistical analysis with the R and Python programming languages.
SPR_.descriptionLong:
This courses teaches Statistics and Probability Theory with emphasis on learning from first principles. To learn advanced Statistics and, in particular, Probability Theory, it is necessary to be familiar with other mathematical topics including Integration, Sequences, Series, Sets, and Combinatrics. Although this course has Statistics and Probability Theory in the title, it contains sufficient supplementary material about other mathematical subjects that is necessary for mastery in Statistics and Probability Theory.

This course also teaches R, the programming language for statistical analysis. You will learn the required programming constructs to perform analysis in this specialized programming language. You will learn to apply the appropriate functions and methods, import and process data, produce meaningful visualizations, and interpret the results of analysis (e.g, Correlation, ANOVA, etc.)

rootDocs.title: Google Meet for Live Office Hours

weeks.weekTitle: Module 1 - Statistics and Probability Theory: Principles
weeks.description: In this week, we will begin by covering an important prerequisite, Mathematical Thinking, which will be about how math is used in Statistics and Probability Theory and the different notations that will be used. We will then go over some fundamental concepts in Statistics and Probability, which will help us to appreciate and quickly understand more advanced topics going forward.

In Module 2, we delve deeper into Probability Theory and other mathematical subjects which are involved in Statistics. We will look at the properties of Random Variables, Probability Distributions, and Moments. In particular, we"ll go over two important topics central to Probability Theory: Expected Values The Normal Distribution.

In Module 3, we will further cover concepts in Mathematical Statistics and study the relationship between multiple explanatory variables in more details. In particular, we will focus on Analysis of Variance (ANOVA). We will look at how Hypothesis Testing and Regression Analysis is performed and better understand tests for Statistical Signigicance.

The Bayesian Theorem (and the algebraic adaptations of it) are at the center of the most powerful machine learning and deep learning models. In this module, we will delve deeper into bayesian methods, discuss the importance of prior and posterior distributions, and understand why bayesian inference is so important in machine learning.

SPR_.event: Attend the Course Q&A on TBD to learn more about this program.

children.title: Derivation of Bayes Theorem X
children.description: In this video, we'll look at the alebraic variations of the Bayes theorem and explain the terms that go into the formulae of the Bayes Theorem.

LMP.title: Linear Mathematics with Python
updateFrequency: New content is added to this course every two weeks
LMP.description: Learn the fundamentals and applications of linear algebra, matrix theory, and linear programming. In this course, you will learn about matrix operations, systems of equations, and optimization in the context of real-world applications and machine learning.

rootDocs.title: Google Meet for Live Office Hours

weeks.description: In the first week, we will create a motivating reason to learn about the applications of matrices and systems of equations. We will understand the development of linear algebra from a historical and practical perspective. The objective of this module is to develop a strong foundation for learning linear algebra and applications of it. Furthermore, this course is based in Python; therefore, we will thoroughly review the programming language and the famous library designed for multidimensional tabular data – NumPy.

weeks.weekTitle: Module 2 & 3 - Matrix Operations and Real-World Applications
weeks.description: In weeks 2 & 3, we will develop a more complete understanding of matrices, the algebra of matrices, and linear programming. In other words, Modules 2 and 3 are about mastering linear algebra and a closely related branch of mathematics called linear programming. Linear algebra is a very important branch of mathematics with very broad applications in the real world, and we will look at applications from economics to quantitative finance to logistics.

weeks.weekTitle: Module 4 -  Machine Learning and Neural Networks
weeks.description: In week 4, we will be introduced to machine learning and neural networks in the context of matrix representation of data. Neural Networks are the center of the most advanced use cases of machine learning such as computer vision and natural language processing. In this module we will look at examples of how matrices are used in machine learning.

LMP.event: Attend the Course Q&A on 27/Jun/2022 to learn more about this program.

children.title: Welcome Video
children.description: Welcome to Linear Mathematics with Python! This video introduces you to the course content, its prerequisites, and the applications of linear mathematics.

children.title: Overview of Linear Algebra
children.description: This video introduces linear algebra as a subset of abstract algebra, discussing its relevance in various contexts. It highlights two main course components: solving systems of linear equations and matrix operations, including concepts like PCA and SVD. The speaker emphasizes practical application through Python programming to understand and implement these techniques effectively. The goal is to connect theoretical concepts to real-world problems, enhancing both linear algebra and Python skills.

children.title: Overview of Linear Programming
children.description: This video discusses linear programming, which is closely related to linear algebra. Linear programming involves an objective function that is either maximized or minimized under specific constraints. It uses graphical methods to depict feasible regions and equations to find solutions. The discussion also touches on topics such as vector operations, trigonometry, and their applications in machine learning, including neural networks. Supplementary materials are provided for prerequisites like classical algebra and geometry. This video explores the graphical representation of inequalities and the process of finding feasible regions for objective functions.

children.title: Basic Example of Linear Programming
children.description: This video discusses linear programming and its relationship to linear algebra. It explains how to solve a system of linear equations, illustrates the process with an example, and mentions the Simplex algorithm. The goal is to find feasible solutions that optimize an objective function. This video also highlights the distinction between linear and nonlinear equations.

children.title: System of Linear Equations
children.description: This video discusses linear programming and its applications in various fields such as economics, finance, and logistics. It emphasizes the use of row operations to simplify solving equations, leading to the reduced row echelon form of matrices. This form helps find solutions by substitution and understanding model behavior. The importance of handling multiple models is highlighted, with Python's capability for quick solutions using libraries like NumPy. This video provides an introduction to the first part of linear algebra, focusing on systems of linear equations.

children.title: Set Builder Notation
children.description: This video discusses set theory and set builder notation. Sets are represented using curly brackets, with elements like numbers. Set builder notation is explained, where sets are defined by conditions on their elements. Various number systems are introduced: natural numbers, integers, rational and irrational numbers, and real numbers. The notation "X such that" or "X:" is used to define sets based on specific conditions.

children.title: Overview of Abstract Algebra - Part 1
children.description: This video discusses abstract algebra concepts such as binary operations, groups, closure, identity, and associativity. It emphasizes the foundational nature of groups in abstract algebra. Groups consist of a set, a binary operation, and adhere to closure, identity, and associativity axioms. Examples and explanations highlight these concepts within the context of arithmetic operations on sets like natural numbers.

children.title: Overview of Abstract Algebra - Part 2
children.description: This video discusses abstract algebra concepts, including groups, rings, fields, linear combinations, and linear spans. It explains how these concepts apply to mathematical objects and vectors. It outlines the definitions of linear combination and linear span, emphasizing sets of vectors formed by combinations of elements.

children.title: Matrices and Spaces
children.description: This video discusses matrices, their notation, and properties. It explains matrix dimensions, row and column spaces, and provides examples. The speaker emphasizes understanding terms for discussions on matrices, neural networks, and 3D plots.

children.title: Exercise 1: Vectors and NumPy
children.description: This video discusses creating and manipulating vectors and matrices using Python. It introduces linear algebra concepts, Python naming conventions, and numpy arrays. The speaker covers vector and matrix creation, conversion to numpy arrays, and performing operations. They emphasize row space elements and suggest tackling the tasks sequentially. The tutorial includes code examples and mentions importing numpy for array manipulation.

children.title: Exercise 1 Solution
children.description: This video introduces using the numpy library to work with vectors and arrays. It discusses creating three vectors, converting them into a matrix, and then converting the matrix into a numpy array. The process includes explanations of numpy functions and the concept of vector addition.

children.title: Linear Programming Practical
children.description: This video discusses an imaginary country exporting grains and the challenge of maximizing profit from container sales. The country faces constraints on container allocation for wheat and barley. The speaker discusses notations, constraints, and the objective function. The task involves finding the feasible region and optimal solution within it. The goal is to maximize profit from selling containers while abiding by constraints. The content touches on mathematical modeling for decision-making in container sales.

children.title: LP Task 1
children.description: This video discusses solving a linear programming (LP) problem with two constraints. The speaker explains how to find feasible points by converting inequalities into equations and then solving for variables. They outline steps to find X and Y values for a given objective function, emphasizing algebraic manipulation. The goal is to locate a point within the feasible region that maximizes profit in an LP problem. They plan to use Python's Matplotlib for visualization.

children.title: LP Task 2
children.description: This video is a tutorial discussing plotting constraints and feasible regions using Python's Matplotlib library. The speaker discusses linear constraints, equations, and graphs to illustrate a feasible region and how to shade it using the fill between method. They highlight the intersection point of constraints and explain the process step by step.

children.title: Linear Programming with Matrix Operations
children.description: This video discusses revisiting a system of equations and linear programming problems. It covers methods like Gaussian elimination and augmented matrices to solve systems of equations more efficiently, highlighting the concept of augmented matrices and their connection to LED composition. The speaker plans to explain solving inequalities through Gaussian elimination later.

children.title: Reduced Row Echelon Form
children.description: This video discusses solving systems of equations using upper triangular matrices and Echelon form. The goal is to achieve reduced row Echelon form by making pivots (numbers across the principal diagonal) equal to one. This process is explained using a matrix example.

children.title: Gaussian Elimination
children.description: This video discusses Gaussian elimination as a method to solve systems of equations, particularly in the context of linear programming. The speaker demonstrates the process of applying Gaussian elimination to a system of inequalities step by step, transforming the system into row-echelon form. They highlight the efficiency of Gaussian elimination and mention that in practical scenarios, computer algebra systems like Matlab or libraries like numpy are used for faster and more accurate solutions.

children.title: Gaussian Elimination with Python
children.description: This video discusses using numpy for matrix operations, including Gaussian elimination, and matrix manipulation. The speaker explains code steps for row operations, subtraction, and replacement in numpy. They touch on inverse matrices and identity matrices as well. This video demonstrates matrix manipulation using Python's numpy library.

children.title: LU Decomposition Overview
children.description: This video discusses linear decomposition of matrices into lower triangular (L) and upper triangular (U) matrices through row elimination. This process involves transforming the original matrix into upper triangular form using elimination matrices. The L component represents the product of elimination matrices, while U is the resulting upper triangular matrix. This technique helps in solving linear equations.

children.title: Elimination Matrices and Identity Matrices
children.description: This video discusses elimination matrices and the process of obtaining upper triangular matrices using row operations. It introduces concepts like the identity matrix and demonstrates matrix multiplication. It emphasizes how multiplication with an identity matrix maintains the original matrix.

children.title: LU Decomposition with Python - Part 1
children.description: This video discusses using elimination matrices to transform matrices. The goal is to eliminate specific elements and achieve upper triangular form. An example with a 3x3 matrix is given, and the process of applying elimination matrices is explained step by step. The narrator modifies the identity matrix to create elimination matrices and demonstrates how they can transform the original matrix.

children.title: LU Decomposition with Python - Part 2
children.description: This video discusses the process of performing matrix elimination operations to transform a given matrix into an upper triangular form. The speaker describes using a sequence of three elimination matrices (E1, E2, E3) to achieve this. The final matrix L is formed by composing these matrices. The goal is to eliminate specific elements in the original matrix and create an upper triangular matrix.

children.title: LU Decomposition with Python - Part 3
children.description: This video discusses matrix operations involving an original matrix, its lower triangular matrix (L), and its upper triangular matrix (U). It highlights the process of multiplying L and U to reconstruct the original matrix. The speaker demonstrates the process of elimination to obtain the upper triangular form and emphasizes the importance of elimination matrices. The goal is to factorize a square matrix into L and U matrices through elimination.

children.title: Vectors
children.description: This video discusses using Python's NumPy library to generate and plot vectors. The speaker defines functions to create, draw, and manipulate vectors. They explain how to plot points on a graph, create sequences of points, and visualize vectors. The goal is to demonstrate vector addition and scalar multiplication. The speaker creates two vectors and their sum, then uses these functions to draw the vectors on a plot.

children.title: Vectors in 3 Dimensions
children.description: This video discusses extending code to create a three-dimensional plot, introducing the z-axis, adapting functions for three dimensions, and explaining the representation of points along each axis. It also mentions using a library for interactive 3D plotting and outlines upcoming topics: polar coordinate systems, vector magnitude, scalar multiplication, and using a specific plotting library.

children.title: Vectors and Cosine Similarity
children.description: This video discusses automatically categorizing words using vector representations and cosine similarity. It explains that words' meanings can be determined by their context, and cosine similarity measures the angle between vectors representing words. Smaller angles indicate closer meanings. Examples with words like "drone," "helicopter," and "rocket" having low angles, while "goose," "eagle," and "B" have larger angles, demonstrate this concept. This video aims to show how to create such a system.

children.title: Cartesian and Polar Coordinate Systems
children.description: This video discusses cosine similarity, polar coordinate system, and vector calculations in Python. It introduces the formula for cosine similarity and explains how to calculate vector magnitudes. The speaker demonstrates Python code to compute vector magnitudes and cosine similarity. They also mention plotting vectors and angles on a graph. This video emphasizes the importance of these concepts in various fields like complex analysis and differential equations.

children.title: Plotting Cosine Similarity
children.description: This video discusses converting between polar and Cartesian coordinate systems. It explains the process of converting vectors, using angles and radii. The speaker demonstrates calculations and uses Python code to visualize the conversions of vectors. They discuss cosine similarity, vector comparisons, and visualization.

children.title: Overview of Linear Transformations
children.description: This video discusses linear transformations, including their properties and examples. It covers how linear transformations relate to vectors, matrices, and systems of linear equations. The speaker explains the conditions for a transformation to be linear and provides examples of linear and non-linear transformations. This video also mentions the application of linear transformations in various fields, including computer vision and neural networks.

children.title: Linear Transformation in Computer Graphics
children.description: In this video, the speaker discusses linear transformations and geometric concepts. They start by creating a new section for linear transformations and drawing vectors on a plot. They mention using functions to abstract away certain details. The speaker talks about moving along the x and y axes, creating vectors, and adjusting their dimensions. They discuss examples of transformations, including skewing and applying shear using matrices, and relate these concepts to computer vision and machine learning.

children.title: Linear Transformation Practical - Part 1
children.description: This video discusses applying shear transformations to vectors and matrices. The speaker demonstrates using code and mathematical explanations to achieve shear effects on objects, such as creating shadows in video games or altering the appearance of a plane. They show how to modify matrix elements to achieve desired effects and visualize the transformations. The process involves manipulating displacement and transformation matrices to create geometric changes. This video emphasizes the practical application of linear transformations to vectors and matrices.

children.title: Linear Transformation Practical - Part 2
children.description: This video discusses creating and manipulating vectors and transformation matrices using Python. It covers topics such as drawing vectors, creating a rotation matrix, converting between degrees and radians, and converting between polar and Cartesian coordinates. The speaker demonstrates two methods for these conversions.

children.title: Determinant Function
children.description: This video discusses matrix determinants, focusing on calculating determinants of square matrices. It explains the process for 2x2 and 3x3 matrices using multiplication along diagonals and across triangles. An example is given for a 2x2 matrix with values, resulting in a determinant of -10. The speaker also hints at practical applications of determinants.

children.title: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
children.description: This video discusses eigenvalues and eigenvectors in linear algebra. It explains how to find eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a given matrix. The process involves steps such as determining the characteristic equation, solving for eigenvalues, constructing a system of equations, and using Gaussian elimination to find eigenvectors. The goal is to find the values and vectors that satisfy certain equations derived from matrix operations.

children.title: Overview of Eigendecomposition
children.description: This video discusses diagonalization of a square matrix using matrices P, D, and P^-1. It highlights the steps to achieve decomposition and explores eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and basis.

children.title: Eigendecomposition - Step 1
children.description: This video discusses finding the characteristic polynomial using the determinant of a matrix. It emphasizes the use of the identity matrix multiplied by a scalar lambda. The goal is to determine the undetermined value of lambda through the determinant function. The process involves multiplying the identity matrix by lambda, resulting in a new matrix with lambda values. This matrix is then used in the determinant function.

children.title: Eigendecomposition - Step 2
children.description: This video explains the process of obtaining a characteristic polynomial using matrix operations. It involves subtracting a product matrix from another matrix and then calculating the determinant. The resulting polynomial is the characteristic polynomial. The process is outlined step by step.

children.title: Eigendecomposition - Step 3
children.description: This video discusses finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors. It explains steps to solve for eigenvalues and demonstrates the process using a matrix. The eigenvectors for each eigenvalue are determined, with an emphasis on the mathematical operations involved. The goal is to reach diagonalization through eigenvector matrix formation.

children.title: Eigendecomposition - Step 4
children.description: This video discusses finding eigenvectors and eigenvalues, particularly the second eigenvalue equal to 4 and its associated eigenvector. These are used to construct a matrix in step 6, with steps being skipped for brevity.

children.title: Eigendecomposition - Step 5
children.description: This video discusses decomposing a matrix into eigenvectors and eigenvalues. P contains eigenvectors, D is a diagonal matrix with eigenvalues. It explains the concept of inversion and how division isn't straightforward in linear algebra. The use of negative exponent for division is illustrated. The process of forming matrices P and D is demonstrated with specific eigenvalues.

children.title: Eigendecomposition - Step 6
children.description: This video discusses matrix inversion through Gaussian elimination. It explains using elimination matrices to transform a matrix into row reduced echelon form, leading to its inverse. This process involves decomposing the matrix into multiple matrices, leading to the original matrix. In the context of SVD, eigenvalues play a crucial role.

children.title: Overview of Singular Value Decomposition
children.description: This video discusses the process of decomposing a matrix using Singular Value Decomposition (SVD). SVD breaks down a matrix into three matrices: U, containing eigenvectors; S, a diagonal matrix of singular values; and V transpose, another orthogonal matrix. The importance of this process is highlighted, along with potential applications such as image compression and dimension reduction.

children.title: Overview of Steps for SVD
children.description: This video discusses the process of calculating the Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) of a matrix. It outlines the steps, including matrix transposition, eigenvalue extraction, and orthogonalization using the Gram-Schmidt algorithm. The speaker explains how to obtain the orthogonal matrix and touches on algorithms like QR decomposition. Overall, the transcript focuses on SVD computation and orthogonalization techniques.

children.title: SVD - Step 1
children.description: This video discusses matrix operations, focusing on transposition and multiplication using the numpy library. It explains how to transpose a matrix, demonstrating the resulting transformation of rows to columns. The speaker uses numpy to calculate the product of a matrix and its transpose, showcasing the final matrix.

children.title: SVD - Step 2
children.description: Transposing and reversing the order of elements in a matrix.

children.title: SVD - Steps 3 & 4
children.description: This video discusses eigenvalues and the calculation of singular values for matrices. The speaker explains how to find eigenvalues using the characteristic polynomial and then focuses on calculating singular values. They show the steps to determine singular values from eigenvalues, denoting them as Sigma₁ and Sigma₂. The process involves taking the square root of the eigenvalues, resulting in Sigma₁ = 14.4 and Sigma₂ = 7.07.

children.title: Orthonormal and Orthogonal Matrices
children.description: This video discusses orthogonal and orthonormal matrices. An orthogonal matrix has perpendicular column vectors, while an orthonormal matrix also has unit magnitude column vectors. The concepts are explained along with the calculation of vector magnitudes and normalization. The speaker introduces terms like normalization and explains their relevance.

children.title: Gram-Schmidt Process
children.description: This video discusses orthogonalization using the Gram-Schmidt algorithm. It outlines creating orthogonal vectors from a given set, addressing conditions for bases, independence, and linear combinations. The algorithm involves creating new vectors using dot products and normalization. It explains the process through an example.

children.title: SVD - Steps 5 & 6
children.description: This video discusses the Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process and its application to matrices. It covers steps involving creating matrices, normalization, orthogonality, and orthonormal matrices. The speaker demonstrates the process using numpy and describes the manual steps. They also mention the Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) algorithm and how it can simplify the process. Ultimately, the speaker shows that applying the Gram-Schmidt process and SVD results in matrices that are orthogonal or orthonormal.

children.title: Principal Component Analysis
children.description: This video discusses the process of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) using numpy in Python. It begins by importing necessary libraries and introduces the concept of principal components and their visualization. The speaker demonstrates using a simple matrix, explaining how to perform Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) and extract the principal components. The goal is to reduce data dimensionality while retaining as much variance as possible. The speaker discusses eigenvalues, SVD composition, and plotting points on x and y axes to visualize the concept. The focus is on understanding PCA before delving into covariance and correlation matrices in a larger dataset example.

children.title: Artificial Intelligence: Fact vs Myth
children.description: This video discusses artificial intelligence (AI) and its various levels, from narrow AI (machine learning for specific tasks) to general AI (human-level intelligence) to super AI (intelligence surpassing humans). The speaker explains that achieving super AI requires replicating human intelligence, but due to limited understanding of the brain, it remains a challenge. Deep learning, an attempt to mimic the brain, is the most advanced technique discussed. This video also touches on the practical and theoretical limitations of achieving such advanced AI capabilities.

children.title: Deep Learning and Neural Networks
children.description: Deep learning aims to replicate the human brain's functioning through perceptrons, the basic units of neurons. Neurons process signals through dendrites, axons, and nuclei. A neuron's perceptron counterpart receives inputs, multiplies them by weights, and passes the result through an activation function. These perceptrons combine in neural networks, with input, hidden, and output layers. Weights are adjusted through backpropagation and gradient descent to minimize prediction errors, enabling learning and pattern recognition in various applications.

children.title: Types of Neural Networks
children.description: This video discusses three types of neural networks: Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLP) for tabular data, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for images, and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) for sequential data. It also touches on sentiment analysis's role in stock trading and explains how CNNs process colored images through convolutional layers. The speaker highlights the significance of matrices and distributions in machine learning and neural networks.

children.title: Mathematical Expression of Neural Networks
children.description: This video discusses an equation from a book by author Charu Aggarwal on machine learning and data mining. The speaker recommends the author's books, highlighting titles like "Machine Learning for Text" and "Data Mining for Healthcare." They analyze the formula involving matrices and activation functions in the context of neural networks. The speaker plans to delve into the mathematical representation and Python implementation for a comprehensive understanding.

children.title: Forecasting with Neural Networks and TensorFlow
children.description: This video discusses the creation of a neural network using TensorFlow and Keras. It covers topics like data preprocessing, creating a sequential model with multiple layers, activation functions, loss functions, and optimization algorithms. The goal is to minimize the Mean Squared Error (MSE) to improve model accuracy. The speaker briefly mentions overfitting and underfitting as issues that can be detected through training and testing. This video emphasizes the practical steps involved in building and evaluating a neural network for regression analysis.

children.title: Image Classification with TensorFlow - Part 1
children.description: This video discusses the process of importing libraries such as TensorFlow and Keras, loading a dataset of images, and understanding its characteristics. The dataset contains 60,000 small color pictures, each belonging to one of ten classes. The goal is to build a model that can classify these images based on their common characteristics. This video also touches on the importance of understanding neural network fundamentals to create and work with more complex models in the future. The speaker demonstrates using commands like 'LS' and explains the structure of tensors in TensorFlow.

children.title: Overview of Train, Validation, and Test
children.description: This video discusses the concepts of neural networks and model training. It covers the perceptron model, features, weights, parameters, validation, underfitting, overfitting, hyperparameters, and the importance of data quality. The training process involves learning parameters, while validation checks for proper metrics and potential overfitting. The final step is testing the model's performance on new data. This video also emphasizes the significance of selecting appropriate models and hyperparameters for effective machine learning.

children.title: Image Classification with TensorFlow - Part 2
children.description: This video discusses the process of working with a dataset of images for training and testing. It involves creating sections in a notebook, importing libraries, and plotting images. The speaker explains steps for creating a grid of pictures, iterating over samples, and labeling images. They encounter and troubleshoot some coding issues before successfully displaying the images in the notebook.

children.title: Image Classification with TensorFlow - Part 3
children.description: This video discusses creating a neural network architecture. It covers the sequential structure with convolutional, max pooling, flat, and dense layers. The architecture involves three convolutional layers, two max pooling layers, one flat layer, and two dense layers. The speaker outlines the layer sequence and expresses the intention to illustrate the architecture visually.

children.title: Image Classification with TensorFlow - Part 3
children.description: This video discusses the construction of a neural network architecture involving convolutional layers, density layers, and Max pool. It mentions the use of matrices (tensors) to represent images' color channels, kernel operations, and the goal of capturing important activations. The speaker refers to a visual representation not fully shown in the transcript.

children.title: Matrix Convolution
children.description: This video discusses the concepts of convolutional layers, filters, and pooling in the context of neural networks. It explains how convolution works for both 1D and 2D data, demonstrating element-wise multiplication and stride calculations. The speaker emphasizes the importance of using filters to detect different features in images, such as vertical, horizontal, or diagonal lines. This video also mentions the recommendation of a specific book on machine learning.

children.title: Filters in Neural Networks
children.description: This video discusses the concept of Max pooling and convolutional neural networks. It explains how filters or kernels are used to identify features like vertical and horizontal lines in images. The process involves convolving the filter with the original matrix to detect signals. This video also mentions using filters to sharpen images and the role of Max pooling in perceiving outlines.

children.title: Max Pooling
children.description: This video discusses Max pooling in convolutional neural networks (CNNs). Max pooling extracts the maximum value from subsections of an input matrix, reducing computational load and achieving translational invariance. It's beneficial for image processing by handling different image sizes, rotations, and illuminations. Max pooling aids feature detection and makes models resilient to variations in input data.

children.title: Neural Network Architecture for Image Classification
children.description: This video explains the setup of a convolutional neural network (CNN) for image analysis. It covers the process of creating convolutional and max pooling layers to identify patterns in images, leading to a flattened distribution that represents the data. The purpose of these layers is to extract features and progressively improve classification. The speaker highlights the need for experimentation in configuring hyperparameters and mentions the softmax activation function and cross-entropy loss for classification. The goal is to determine the most likely classes for the input image.

children.title: Image Classification with TensorFlow - Part 4
children.description: This video discusses reviewing code for a neural network model, explaining activation functions, model architecture, and parameters. It covers compiling the model with an optimizer and loss function, including an explanation of cross entropy. The goal is to minimize loss and maximize accuracy. The model's structure, parameters, and training strategy are detailed.

children.title: Training the Neural Network Model
children.description: This video discusses training and evaluating a machine learning model. It mentions training the model using images, checking for overfitting, using a test dataset for validation, and adjusting the number of epochs for better performance. The speaker also talks about potential issues with longer training times and using different tiers in Colab environment.

children.title: Activations in Neural Networks (Graph Representation)
children.description: This video discusses topics related to deploying machine learning models and activation functions. It covers concepts such as saving model weights, deploying models to cloud platforms, and different activation functions. The speaker explains how inputs and weights are used to calculate values for perceptrons in a neural network's hidden layer and introduces various activation functions. Linear activation is discouraged for hidden layers.

children.title: Activation Functions
children.description: This video discusses the concept of a perceptron in neural networks. The perceptron acts as a mathematical model representing a human brain neuron. It processes signals and determines whether they're strong enough for activation, based on a threshold. This video also touches on bias values and activation functions, illustrating how the perceptron decides whether input data corresponds to a property or not. This process involves comparing the input's size to a threshold and using activation functions to make a classification decision.

children.title: Activations in Neural Networks (Matrix Representation)
children.description: This video explains matrix representation, activation functions, and neural network layers. It covers how matrix multiplication isn't commutative, describing components of vectors, bias, and activation. It emphasizes passing through activation functions for layer outputs and their applications in classification, such as fraud detection.

children.title: Intuitive Explanation of Neural Networks
children.description: This video explains the concept of a simplified neural network using a triangle image as an example. Perceptrons in hidden layers focus on individual features, and subsequent layers combine these to identify the overall shape. The process is intuitive, aiming to recognize the triangle from its parts through a neural network.

children.title: Overview of Hyperparamters in TensorFlow Playground
children.description: This video discusses neural networks, activation functions, and hyperparameters. It illustrates the use of different activation functions for separating classes of data. The presenter demonstrates how the choice of activation function, such as tanh and ReLU, affects the network's ability to classify data points correctly. They emphasize the importance of non-linear activation functions for complex data patterns and highlight the impact of hyperparameter tuning on model performance. The example showcases how neural networks adapt over epochs to form appropriate boundaries between data classes using specific activation functions.

children.title: Image Classification with TensorFlow - Part 5
children.description: This video discusses model accuracy improvement during training, reaching 75% from 36%, albeit with non-zero loss due to data limitations. The speaker prepares to plot classification metrics, normalizes an image, and employs the predict method with softmax function for class probability distribution. The upcoming focus is on softmax and cross-entropy functions for analysis.

children.title: Probability, Classification, and Sigmoid Function
children.description: This video discusses the softmax and sigmoid functions, their use in classification, odds ratios, logarithmic transformations, logistic regression, and the derivation of the sigmoid function's formula. It emphasizes how logarithmic transformations help rescale probabilities and introduces logistic regression concepts.

children.title: Example of Logistic Regression for Classification
children.description: This video discusses a GitHub link for viewing a model's sigmoid function. The function adjusts classifications and plots them. A red line represents the model's prediction boundary. This video also mentions the expit function, which pushes for true classification and lowers for false.

CSApp.title: Computer Science and Applications
CSApp.summary:
This beginner-friendly course teaches programming and computer science through application development with JavaScript and the NodeJS ecosystem. You will learn how to develop the different components of a complete application (fullstack) and, in the process, the importance of various topics of computer science such data structures, computer networks, and computer organization. Additionally, you learn to deploy your app to the Google Cloud Platform.

 You will have the option to specialize your certificate in areas such Fullstack Development, CS Theory, Cybersecurity, Data Analysis, or general Computer Science.
CSApp.description: Learn computer science and programming with modern application development. Choose to specialize in an area such as CS theory, fullstack devleopment, data analysis, or cybersecurity.
highlights: Beginner-friendly course. Includes advanced content for intermediate learners.
Covers the applications and theory of computer science.
Intuitive explanations of programming and theoretical topics
Step-by-step breakdown of complex technical concepts.
Learn through programming, exercises, and practical real-world applications.
First-principles teaching style. Learn from elementary to advanced concepts.
updateFrequency: New content is added to this course weekly

weeks.description: The first module of the course will introduce to main programming constructs in found in almost all programming languages such as variables, control statements, functions, and basic data structures. JavaScript is both a general purpose programming language and loosely typed, which means many applications can be built with it and it is reletively easy to learn.

The most important skill for any programmer is the understanding of and implementation of data structures. Mastering data structures requires the understanding of how computers organize and process data. The better your understanding of data structures, the better your problem solving abilities.

In this module, you will learn the fundamentals of creating a user interface (UI) and to control the behaviour of the UI element with event binding and listening. You will learn to organize a UI with the HTML markup language and control elements with JavaScript. Design systems and styling (via CSS) will be covered as independent learning.

HyperText Transfer Protocol is the set of methods by which data is exchanged between computers in the Internet. To understand HTTP is to understand how computers exchange data, and this level of understanding is key for building applications — in particular backend applications. You will learn to develop and work with APIs, the OSI layer, and connect your UI and backend apps together via HTTP.

This module will cover the different types of database systems and their use cases. Additionally, you will learn to use and host data on the MongoDB database service, which is a popular graph-based (or NoSQL) database management system used in a wide variety of applications. You will learn how to configure a MongoDB cluster, connect to it from an application, and perform CRUD operations via Mongo shell and the Mongoose library.

In this module, we combine what we learn about computer networks and databases to build a prototye application for interfacing between the UI and the database. We will learn to use the Git CLI (command line interface) for both version control and its role in DevOps (developer operations).  We will in more detail look at API development using OpenAPI and

GCS, or Google Cloud Computing, is a service from Google for running applications and storing data in Google data centers. Cloud computing, generally speaking, is the about using clusters of specialized computers for running process that are intensive with respect to processing, storage, memory, or networking (or all of these). You will learn general concepts in cloud computing and how to deploy your app and store data on GCS.
In this module, you can choose a specialization for your professional certification. You can choose from one of the following topics to specialize in:

extra.title: Computer Science
extra.description: This covers computer science more broadly wit special focus on computer organization, computer architecture, and low level programming. In particular, C++ will be covered as this is both a low-level and high-level programming language, which helps us to appreciate how computers work from the application level all the way down to the hardware level.
highlights: C++ & Computer Memory
Computer Organization
Computer Networking

extra.title: CS Theory
extra.description: This specialization focus on discrete mathematics, the most important branch of mathematics in computer science. Discrete mathematics will provide us with the tools to analyze the performance, theoretically, of algorithms. Moreover, will look at more advanced graph data structures – the understanding of which requires a good foundation in discrete mathenatics.
highlights: Discrete Mathematics
Languages and Automata
Analysis of Algorithms
Advanced Data Structures

extra.title: Cybersecurity
extra.description: This specialization is centered on cryptography, the mathematics of it, and the algorithms that allow for data to be securely transmitted and stored. Additionally, we will cover aspects of vulnerabilities with respect to digital exchange of data, and what methods are used to address these vulnerabilities.
highlights: Mathematics for Cryptography
Cryptographic Algorithms
Penetration Testing
Ethical Hacking

extra.title: Fullstack Development
extra.description: This specialization teaches ReactJS and NextJS. The former is library for UI state management and the latter is a library (and framework) for building React-based fullstack applications. You will learn about React concepts, such as states, props, hooks, contexts, and conditional rendering. You will also learn the ins-and-outs of NextJS for provision a backend app for your fullstack app. Unit-testing will be covered as independent learning.
highlights: NextJS
ReactJS
ExpressJS
MaterialUI

extra.title: Data Analysis
extra.description: A new discipline that relies greatly on the power of computers and computer programming is data science.           This specialization covers the aspects of comptuer scienec relevant to data science such as Python, data preprocessing, APIs, BASH scripting, the NumPy library, and descriptive statistics – which provides a good foundation for the more advanced inferential statistics.
highlights: Python and Data Science Libraries
Data Preprocessing
Descriptive Statistics
Data Visualization

NumPy.title: NumPy with Applications - Dubai
NumPy.summary:
NumPy is a library for performing matrix operations in the Python programming language. This library is used both directly and indirectly (in other libraries) for all kinds of computational applications such as image processing, statistics, machine learning, and numerical methods.

 To make the best use of NumPy, you need to be competent in both (1) programming and (2) linear algebra. Linear algebra is the algebra of special types of sets called vectors, and the general cases of which include matrices and tensors. 

In this course, you will be given an overview of the NumPy library, Linear Algebra, and example applications in image processing. You will learn enough of the fundamentals to more quickly advance your understanding of NumPy and the libraries that are built on top of NumPy such Pandas, TensorFlow, and PyTensor.
NumPy.description: Deep dive into NumPy and learn the fundamentals of matrix operations. Learn to apply various NumPy methods with applications in image processing.
NumPy.pricing: For certification option: AED 650 (inclusive of VAT)
highlights: Beginner-friendly course. Includes advanced content for intermediate learners.
Covers some applications and theory of linear algebra.
Intuitive explanations of programming and theoretical topics
Step-by-step breakdown of complex technical concepts.
Learn through programming, exercises, and practical real-world applications.
First-principles teaching style. Learn from elementary to advanced concepts.
updateFrequency: New content is added to this course weekly

weeks.description: In day 1, you will be introduction to the main object of the NumPy library, nd.array, and its attributes and methods. You will learn how to process data with basic NumPy methods and how to access sections in multidimensional data. You will also apply what you learn to solve a practical data processing problem

In day 2, you will be introduced to fundamental concepts in linear algebra, including algebra axioms, gaussian elimination, matrix inversion, determinants, echelon form matrices, identity matrices, and others. You will apply what you learn about linear algebra to solve a system of equations.

In the final module, you will learn the basic of image processing and computer vision, with technqiues such as filters and convolutions. You will learn to use NumPy to preprocess and manipulate images as a practical exercise. Finally, you will be guided towards learning more advanced applications of NumPy and linear algebra

SQL.description: Learn the basics of SQL and relational databases in this course designed for beginners in data science, data engineering, and application development.
SQL.title: Introduction to SQL

weeks.description: In this module, you will learn the syntax of Structured Query Language and how to write procedures for CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.

MPD.description: Discover the fundamental concepts in mathematics through computer programming. Become proficient in both mathematics and programming. Gain key skills for mathematical sciences such as computer science, data science, and engineering.
MPD.descriptionLong:
This course covers programming in Python, the fundamentals Computer Science, and the fundamentals of Mathematics. In addition to learning to program in Python, you will understand, at the high level, how computers work and interpret programming languages. A high-level understanding of computer architecture will allow you to understand the most complex of algorithms and data structures. This course, which is the foundation couse for more advanced courses at BigNumber, is self-contained and focused on the first-principles of Computer Science and Pure Mathematics.

Pure Mathematics is about concepts in mathematics that are ubiquitous in all of Mathematics. In this course, you will learn the building blocks of mathematics that are relevant and necessary in all of the Mathematical and the Physical Sciences (e.g, Computer Science, Data Science, Engineering, and Economics).
MPD.title: Mathematics and Programming

rootDocs.title: Google Meet for Live Office Hours

weeks.weekTitle: Module 1 - Introduction to Programming and Computer Science
weeks.description: In the first week, we will learn the building blocks of a programming language and implementation of algorithms. We will learn to write algorithms in sequential, conditional, and iterative patterns. For data structures, we will go in depth about linear data structures, their methods, and algorithms for searching in and writing into data structures.
weeks.details:
Topics:
  • Overview of Computer Science
  • Overview of Programming and Computer Organization
  • Getting Started with Python
  • Control Statements
  • Data Structures: Lists
  • Data Structures: Dictionaries, Sets, and Tuples
  • Classes and Objects
  • Time & Space Complexity

weeks.description: In week 2, we will use our understanding of programming as a bridge to understand fundamental mathematical concepts and syntax. Symbols and terminology will be introduced to you and you will be able recognize mathematical objects in any branch of mathematics. We will cover functions, sets and relations, logic, proofs and mathematical induction. We will then apply these mathematical concepts directly in programming.
weeks.details:
Assessment:
You will complete assignments about topics covered in Module 2.
Topics:
  • Overview of Pure Mathematics
  • Overview of Discrete Mathematics
  • Logic, Axiom, Lemma, Corollary, and Theorem
  • Accumulation, Sequence and Series
  • Maps and Functions
  • Sets and Relations
  • Mathematical Induction
  • Recursion

weeks.weekTitle: Module 3 -  Discrete Mathematics and Advanced Programming
weeks.description: In week 3, we will develop our mathematical proficiency in Discrete Mathematics by exploring and working with examples of graphs, which are mathematical objects with broad applications in both Computer Science and Data Science. Furthermore, we will learn about Languages, Grammars, and Finite State Machines. From there, we will apply what we have learned to Graph Data Structures and then Regular Expressions.
weeks.details:
Topics:
  • Graph Theory
  • Directed Graphs
  • Finite State Machines
  • Regular Expressions
  • Graph Data Structures
  • Combinatorics
  • Capstone Project

MPD.event: Attend the Course Q&A on 08/May/2022 to learn more about this program.

children.title: Review of Time and Space Complexity
